item.title: Borderlands 4 is Giving an Overlooked BL3 Feature a Second Wind
item.description:
When Borderlands 4 gameplay was first shown off, one of the more curious reveals was the return (rather than replacement) of Radiation. The element first appeared in Borderlands 3 , but never fully reached the iconic status of Borderlands 2 ’s fifth element, Slag, in part because no Vault Hunter was built to harness it fully. Following the reveal of Harlowe’s new skill trees, however, it seems that Borderlands 4 intends to give the element another opportunity to shine.

Replacing explosives in Borderlands ' element rotation, Radiation spread damage between enemies and punished clustered groups, but the lack of visual impact left it feeling no more special than the other elements. Harlowe’s kit breathes new life into the status effect, finally giving it the focus it needed it lacked in Borderlands 3 . Through Harlowe's Creative Bursts skill tree, Radiation becomes a core part of her damage identity, offering both passive boosts and active effects that could elevate the element into the spotlight.

Borderlands 4’s Harlowe Redefines Radiation Through Chain Reaction Chaos

Borderlands 3 's Radiation was best used to chain damage from one enemy to another. When a target died while irradiated, it exploded into a damaging nova with the chance to spread the effect further. A subtle feature that added character to the element, it could also contaminate pools of water to create temporary spots of AoE damage.

As such, Radiation was best utilized to clear out clustered mobs. The element had a clear thematic identity, but without a dedicated playstyle to enhance it, the effect simply didn’t scale as effectively as other elements. Harlowe’s skills in Borderlands 4 bridge that gap through certain active abilities and passive upgrades, each focused on multiplying potential opportunities for chain reactions.

Harlowe’s CHROMA Accelerator Means More Explosions, More Often

The key to her Radiation synergy lies in Harlowe's CHROMA Accelerator Action Skill. The skill allows Harlowe to fire an Unstable Energy Pocket that inflicts Cryo damage as it passes near enemies, but the kicker is that activating the skill again triggers a massive detonation that deals heavy Radiation damage across a wide area. This creates immediate synergy with her passive trait, Entanglement, which links enemies affected by her Action Skills for extra gun damage, making Harlowe potentially one of Borderlands 4 's best Vault Hunters.

By introducing passives that expand how she can irradiate targets, the middle branch of Harlowe's Creative Bursts skill tree could enable a devastating endgame Radiation build. The Fissile Launcher passive causes Radiation darts to be shot at another enemy when Harlowe damages an irradiated or entangled enemy, while the Dirty Bomb skill causes enemies to explode whenever hit with the status effect. The capstone skill, Demon Core, continues to stack on the damage by allowing her Unstable Energy Pocket to pepper foes with even more irradiated darts, for even more elemental explosions.

The Special Purpose Magnets Augment also allows Harlowe's Unstable Energy Pocket to pull enemies along, while also dealing increased damage to every enemy it has already hit when detonated.

Big Damage and Skill Versatility Mean Harlowe Could Be Borderlands 4’s Best Vault Hunter

What makes her an even more exciting Vault Hunter is that Radiation synergy is only one part of one of Harlowe's three Action Skills. Zero-Point, another of Harlowe's abilities, uses Stasis to entangle and lock down enemies or smash them into the ground. Meanwhile, Flux Generator is a deployable Cryo-damage field that buffs allies while also entangling nearby foes.

These alternate Action Skills suggest that, despite a dizzying damage potential, Harlowe can flex to also provide both area control and team utility, depending on which skill tree players invest in. This versatility could make Harlowe the most flexible Vault Hunter in the Borderlands franchise. Should that design philosophy extend to each of Borderlands 4 Vault Hunters, the game could set a new standard for endgame build diversity.

The synergy of crowd control and constant passive explosions makes Harlowe's CHROMA Accelerator the most appealing choice for exploring the possible endgame of Borderlands 4 so far, however. Whether or not it will rival the most dominant elemental builds of past games remains to be seen, but for the first time since its introduction, Radiation has a dedicated champion to showcase its destructive flair. If the tree is actually as powerful as it looks, Borderlands 4 could revitalize one of the franchise’s most underutilized elements.

item.title: Criterion’s Battlefield Rebrand Is the End of the Road for Need for Speed
item.description:
Electronic Arts currently appears to be in the process of rebranding Criterion Games with the purpose of identifying it as "a Battlefield studio." The move marks the end of an era for Criterion's Need for Speed franchise, though it's still unclear whether another era will follow.

The Guildford-based developer's attention has been divided between Need for Speed and Battlefield for years now. The 2018 Battlefield 5 featured a battle royale mode made by Criterion, with the studio being given an even bigger role in the development of Battlefield 2042 , released in 2021. This resulted in Need for Speed Unbound slipping into 2022. The British company then found itself working on Battlefield 6 not long afterward, stating that the Need for Speed franchise was going on a hiatus in the meantime.

New Criterion Logo Suggests Battlefield-Only Future for the NFS Developer

The ongoing break may turn out to be of the permanent variety, as suggested by Criterion's new logo, first spotted by Reddit user aleyyyy420 (via TheGamer). The graphic features a white variant of the company's old logo, but with "A Battlefield Studio" tagline attached to it from below. It can currently only be found in the footer of EA's Criterion Games page, where it wasn't present as late as July 2025, according to cached web data reviewed by Game Rant. This suggests that the rebranding is currently ongoing, and may yet be accompanied by an official announcement of Criterion going the Battlefield -only route.

Another Studio Could Take Over NFS from Criterion

The move aligns with EA’s history of folding independent subsidiaries into larger franchise ecosystems and repurposing them as support studios. With Criterion now seemingly beholden to Battlefield , the company appears unable to uphold its February 2025 pledge that the Need for Speed franchise will continue. Another EA studio could take over, with the most obvious candidate being Codemasters, the F1 developer that's presently winding down its WRC development efforts because EA is losing the license for the franchise in 2027. However, Codemasters has recently faced layoffs following the licensing news, raising doubts about whether it can immediately begin a new project on a timeline comparable to Criterion’s while still maintaining its F1 development efforts.

Criterion's rebranding and refocusing lends credence to a July 2025 report claiming EA has shelved Need for Speed indefinitely. The publisher's diminishing interest in the series is likely related to Need for Speed Unbound falling short of its predecessor's sales, something that was never officially confirmed but can be gleaned from publicly available player data and third-party estimates.

For fans still holding out hope for a Burnout revival, this news dims those prospects even further. In the meantime, all eyes are on Battlefield 6 , which is slated for release on October 10.

Source: EA [cached]

item.title: Wonderful Open-World Games That Let You Experience True Freedom
item.description:
Summary

  • True freedom: ignore the main quest and leisurely explore huge sandboxes without artificial limits.
  • Be knight, thief, mercenary or outlaw - Kingdom Come II and Red Dead 2 let emergent, immersive play flourish.
  • No Man's Sky, Enshrouded and Fallout 76 offer boundless worlds, procedural galaxies, and unique traversal.

Freedom is something rare to find, even in Open-World games . No matter how huge their sandboxes are, there's always something that blocks the path of players or diverts their attention from the main quest. But there are a few selected titles that allow players to experience 'true freedom.'

Be it that they allow players to ignore the Main Quest indefinitely and explore leisurely, or that their main objectives have no strings attached, these titles are the best Open-World games to spend hours exploring leisurely or choosing your own adventure.

Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2

Be A Knight, Be A Thief, Be A Mercenary, Or A Pig

12 Images
12 Images
Kingdom Come: Deliverance II
10 /10
64
9.1 /10
Released
February 4, 2025

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
Mature 17+ // Use of Alcohol, Blood and Gore, Sexual Content, Strong Language, Intense Violence, Partial Nudity
Powered by

Of all the possible choices for players to experience the thrill of the audacious medieval life, the Kingdom Come series has done more than most by including a huge world to explore, filled to the brim with colorful characters, vicious bandits, and dangerous wolves prowling around its foresty areas. The second iteration of the series, Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2, has two enormous sandboxes where players can let lose and wander for hours, discovering hundreds of secrets and dozens of quests.

They can choose the path of the honorable Knight, or perhaps dedicate their days to scamming people playing dice at the taverns, or they can even turn into poachers and bandits if they wish to. There's no correct way to play KCD2, and the best part: Players don't have a countdown over their heads, nor significant barriers blocking their relaxing exploration. It is true freedom in Bohemia, and with its Hardcore Mode active, it becomes a magnificent medieval life simulator.

No Man's Sky

An Endless Sea Of Stars To Navigate At Your Own Pace

5 Images
5 Images
No Man's Sky
7 /10
62
9.3 /10
Released
August 9, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Fantasy Violence, Animated Blood
Developer(s)
Hello Games
Publisher(s)
Hello Games
Powered by

Nothing compares to the sensation of having literally unlimited space to fly, and from all similar games, No Man's Sky has become the stuff of legend. With an enormous community-driven universe to explore, players can become space traders, prospectors, conquerors, or xenobiologists.

By discovering new species and updating the community database, naming planets and animals, players not only acquire credits but also put their mark on this ever-expanding game, where there is no true limit to exploration. With over 200 different galaxies and hundreds of millions of planets, there's no way anyone has seen it all in this procedurally generated game. The thing is, there's no single way to play this game, and with the regular content drops and Expeditions, no playthrough is the same as the previous one. This game has aged wonderfully, and it will continue to expand into the infinite and beyond.

Red Dead Redemption 2

Lose Track Of Time, Wild West Style

Red Dead Redemption 2
10 /10
168
9.5 /10
Released
October 26, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Nudity, Sexual Content, Strong Language, Use of Drugs and Alcohol
Developer(s)
Rockstar Games
Powered by

From the dangerous and treacherous Grizzlies, to the majestic views of Big Valley, Red Dead Redemption 2 is arguably the best game ever made by Rockstar, with a huge potential for replay value and a level of freedom that few games of the western genre have granted their players.

Even its predecessors already had a certain special touch, although Red Dead Revolver was entirely linear, and only in Red Dead Redemption devs decided to go for the big sandbox and grant players the ability to forge their own wild-west legend. Still, this magnificent Open-World game has tons of hours of content to explore, and only the most gritted cowboys (and outlaws) will be able to see it all, and collect all the trophies/achievements to platinum. It's a massive game that makes players lose themselves in the world, riding into the sunset.

Enshrouded

Forge Your Own Path Through The Deadly Shroud

Enshrouded
7.7 /10
Released
January 24, 2024

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Developer(s)
Keen Games
Platform(s)
PC
Powered by

Enshrouded is a gratifying and unique experience that allows players to explore a world devastated by a mysterious fog called The Shroud. Players are survivors from an ancient order that can push back this plague that ravages the land, and they will do so by lighting powerful beacons of mystical fire, building their bases, and eliminating the Shroud Roots that cause the fog to extend through the Embervale.

The game is still under construction, but players can already enjoy a vast Open-World map, which allows them to explore leisurely at their own pace, without caring for following a main quest. There are hundreds of quests and objectives to unlock, since players need to rescue other survivors like them, NPCs that will assist with crafting new and powerful gear to keep advancing and fighting against The Shroud. The addition of a Grappling Hook to climb and balance between cliffs, and a flysuit, grants this game some unique traversal mechanics that few other Open-World Survival RPGs have. With its Wake of the Water update right around the corner, there has never been a better time to try this game and see how much it has to offer.

Fallout 76

One Of The Most Complete Fallout Experiences You'll Ever Find

Fallout 76
5 /10
44
8.2 /10
Released
November 14, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Drug Reference, Intense Violence, Strong Language, Use of Alcohol
Developer(s)
Bethesda
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 4, Xbox One
Powered by

Fallout 76 is a weird game: It has everything that a good Fallout game should have, but at the same time, it deviates from the norm in various aspects. For starters, players are not forced to chase after a dangerous enemy or bring back retribution to someone who has left them for dead. Instead, they are looking for the rest of the Vault Dwellers and following the trace of a mysterious plague that ravages Appalachia.

The game starts on the Reclamation Day, when all Vault Dwellers were supposed to go above ground and start rebuilding, though their plans are quickly thwarted by the vicious mutated creatures and inhospitable weather conditions (it's hard to build a town when radioactive rain and mutated giant bats are turning everyone into plague-ridden zombies). But perhaps, the most wonderful detail about this MMORPG, is that it allows its players a level of freedom to build their characters and explore the map like no other Fallout game has ever done. With a wonderful and caring community and a fully integrated housing system, Fallout 76 continues to get better and better, offering tons of hours of fun exploring post-apocalyptic West Virginia.

item.title: Final Fantasy 14 Director Shares When Two Dawntrail Features Should Appear
item.description:
Final Fantasy 14 producer and director Naoki Yoshida stated that both the Beastmaster Limited Job and the next Ultimate Raid are tentatively scheduled to launch in Patch 7.5 or subsequent updates. However, given the current patch release cadence of Final Fantasy 14 , the 7.5 update is tentatively scheduled for the first half of 2026.

Yoshida's statement came after Final Fantasy 14 launched Patch 7.3, The Promise of Tomorrow, which was the climactic update of Dawntrail's main story. Although Patch 7.3's main content was split across three updates, the majority of it went live on August 5, which saw a new alliance raid, San d'Oria: The Second Walk, along with balance changes to Jobs like the Viper and the Pictomancer. However, Final Fantasy 14 's 7.3 update was also notorious for a notable omission, as Dawntrail's second Ultimate Raid was notably absent.

Final Fantasy 14's Beastmaster and Next Ultimate Raid Have A Release Window

However, Final Fantasy 14 raid teams looking to sink their teeth into another Ultimate raid now have a potential window. In an interview with PCGamesN during Gamescom in Cologne, Germany, Yoshida said that work on both the next Ultimate raid and the Beastmaster Limited Job is ongoing, and that both have a release window that aligns with Patch 7.5. Currently, Final Fantasy 14 releases major content patches on a four-month cadence. Given that Patch 7.3 went live on August 5, Patch 7.4 could go live in mid to late December 2025, or be pushed back to January 2026, should Square Enix choose to take a break for the winter holidays. If the cadence holds, Patch 7.5 will not arrive until Spring 2026 at the earliest. Yoshida said, "I think that will also be quite a unique experience, so players who really like to tackle high-end battle content should be able to really enjoy that."

It is unclear what the subject of the next Ultimate raid will be, so Final Fantasy 14 fans must wait for more information. As for the long-awaited Beastmaster, it will be the second Limited Job added to Final Fantasy 14 following the release of the Blue Mage in early 2019. Further details about the Beastmaster, including its weapon and abilities, are currently unknown.

In the meantime, Final Fantasy 14 players will soon have a new challenge, as Guardian Arkveld from Monster Hunter Wilds will appear in early October as part of a crossover. Given how much content awaits Final Fantasy 14 players, only time will tell if it will be enough to sate appetites ahead of the game's next expansion.

item.title: After 7 Years, Hollow Knight: Silksong’s Development is a Pandora’s Box Waiting to Be Opened
item.description:
Few games have been as highly anticipated as Hollow Knight: Silksong and its development story alone is equally endearing and fascinating. It’s incredibly amusing and fortunate, then, that Team Cherry itself describes this immense seven-year undertaking as “fun,” disregarding any misguided theories fans could have about that period being one of ‘development hell’ simply because of how long it was. Ultimately, Hollow Knight: Silksong ’s final product will be one that was decided on despite Team Cherry having more than enough ideas to last several more years in development, and that content could make for a terrific slate of DLCs.

Indeed, with Hollow Knight: Silksong allowing Team Cherry to bask in ‘development heaven’ for the last seven years, it’s exciting to imagine how the sequel’s DLCs will take shape. There may even be a reasonably reliable timeline for when players can expect to see the first of however many Hollow Knight: Silksong DLCs, so long as Team Cherry’s process is similar to what the studio used for its debut game. Likewise, if that process truly is comparable, it’s wholly possible that Team Cherry relishing and enjoying the development process as much as it does could result in a third Hollow Knight installment, either purposefully or inadvertently.

Hollow Knight’s DLCs Tell a Tale That May Be Retold via Silksong

Team Cherry is looking far beyond launch and apparently has “ambitious” plans for Hollow Knight: Silksong ’s post-launch content. As for Hollow Knight , the original game’s DLCs included:

  • Hidden Dreams (Patch 1.1.1.6), released August 3, 2017.
  • The Grimm Troupe (Patch 1.2.1.0), released October 26, 2017.
  • Lifeblood (Patch 1.3.1.5), released April 20, 2018.
  • Godmaster (Patch 1.4.2.4), released August 23, 2018.

If this series of DLCs is in any way a blueprint for how Team Cherry might launch Hollow Knight: Silksong ’s own, it wouldn’t be out of the realm of possibility for the first DLC to be released roughly six months after the base game is released—March 2026, perhaps, seeing as how Hollow Knight: Silksong ’s release date is in a week and a half, on September 4, 2025. Plus, if Team Cherry manages to settle on the same number of DLCs of the same scale as those in Hollow Knight: Silksong ’s predecessor, the sequel’s DLCs may conclude with a final one releasing a year and a half after the base game’s launch.

Team Cherry could have more than four DLCs planned for Hollow Knight: Silksong , of course. However, a likelier option than producing five or more DLCs may be to recycle the past and choose one that’s more transformative or significant from the bunch and flesh it out into its own elaborate and standalone game.

With Hollow Knight: Silksong allowing Team Cherry to bask in ‘development heaven’ for the last seven years, it’s exciting to imagine how the sequel’s DLCs will take shape.

Hollow Knight: Silksong’s Development Heaven May Be Quite Fruitful

It’s probably too early to predict with any certainty whether Team Cherry will endeavor to work on a third Hollow Knight game once it decides it’s finished with this sequel’s content. That said, Team Cherry co-founder Ari Gibson stating cheekily that Hollow Knight: Silksong could’ve taken 15 years to release due to how many fun and neat ideas were being produced suggests that there’s a seemingly infinite well of inspiration and content that could nourish another sequel. With how much content Team Cherry has lying around that it could perfume multiple DLCs and sequels with, it would be rather odd if Hollow Knight ’s legacy quit at the height of its zenith.

Knowing that Hollow Knight: Silksong was originally conceived as Hollow Knight DLC before growing up to be its own full-fledged game, the same could logically happen to any number of DLCs that the sequel might otherwise bear.

If the same development process was utilized for a possible third entry in the Hollow Knight franchise, players would probably be strapping themselves in for another seven years or more of eager waiting. This time, though, there’d at least be an expectation of development taking over half a decade and no need for anyone to don clown makeup for the foreseeable future.
